hypotheses: Rising consumer affluence reduces the share of employment in manufacturing (deindustrialization).
Unbalanced productivity growth (manufacturing productivity rising faster than services) reduces manufacturing employment.
Globalization (especially increased imports from low-wage countries and related FDI) reduces domestic manufacturing employment.
claim.hypotheses_location: Introduction and literature review / early sections of the paper (where the three factors—affluence, productivity growth, and globalization—are introduced as testable causes).
claim.statement: Rising consumer affluence is the most important driver of deindustrialization in advanced economies, more so than productivity growth or globalization.
claim.statement_location: Abstract, introduction and conclusions (paper repeatedly emphasizes affluence as the largest contributor across results and the conclusion).

data.source: Panel data assembled from OECD sources (including the STAN database), the UN National Accounts Main Aggregates Database, and trade and FDI statistics (disaggregated by trading partner regions).
data.wave_or_subset: Panel of 18 OECD countries covering years 1970–2003.
data.sample_size: Panel of 18 countries over 1970–2003 (approximately 18 × 34 = 612 country-year observations; paper describes analysis over 18 countries from 1970 to 2003).
data.access_details: Data drawn from OECD STAN and UN National Accounts and standard international trade/FDI statistics. The paper does not provide specific data access links or detailed access procedures.
data.notes: Variables constructed include relative manufacturing employment (share of workforce), real per-capita income (national affluence) with squared and cubed terms, unbalanced productivity growth (manufacturing vs. services), trade shares disaggregated by North/South and imports/exports (% of GDP), and net outflow of FDI (% of GDP). The authors detected and removed seven outliers using the Hadi robust outlier detection algorithm; explanatory variables were lagged by one year; tests indicated serial correlation, spatial correlation, and groupwise heteroskedasticity which were corrected in estimation (FE-GLS).

method.description: The study uses panel regression analyses with two-way fixed effects on a panel of 18 OECD countries (1970–2003) to simultaneously test three proposed causes of deindustrialization: rising national affluence, unbalanced productivity growth (manufacturing vs. services), and globalization (trade and FDI). The authors add nonlinear terms (squared and cubed) for income and productivity to capture nonlinearity, disaggregate trade by partner regions (North vs. South) and by direction (imports vs. exports), apply period (five-year) dummies, test for panel data issues (serial correlation, spatial correlation, heteroskedasticity), detect and remove outliers (Hadi algorithm), lag explanatory variables by one year, and estimate using fixed-effects generalized least squares (FE-GLS). They also estimate system models (FE-3SLS / 3SLS) to assess direct and indirect effects and validate robustness.
steps: Assemble country-year panel data for 18 OECD countries for 1970–2003 from OECD STAN, UN National Accounts, and trade/FDI statistics.
Construct dependent variable: relative manufacturing employment (share of workforce in manufacturing).

Construct key independent variables: real per-capita income (national affluence) and its squared and cubed terms; unbalanced productivity growth between manufacturing and services; trade variables disaggregated into imports/exports to/from the South and North (expressed as % of GDP); net FDI outflows (% of GDP); control variables including unemployment and period dummies.
Apply a one-year lag to all explanatory variables.
Detect outliers using the Hadi robust outlier detection algorithm and remove identified outliers (seven observations removed).

Run two-way fixed-effects regressions and perform postestimation diagnostic tests (Wooldridge for serial correlation, modified Breusch-Pagan for spatial correlation, modified Wald for groupwise heteroskedasticity).
Estimate FE models corrected via generalized least squares (FE-GLS) to address serial correlation, spatial correlation, and heteroskedasticity.

Estimate system equations (FE-3SLS / 3SLS) to model direct and indirect effects (e.g., impacts of North-South trade on national affluence and unbalanced productivity growth and their subsequent effects on manufacturing employment) and to check robustness.
Decompose estimated effects to attribute percentages of deindustrialization to affluence, trade, productivity, unemployment, and period effects.
method.models: Two-way fixed-effects regression; fixed-effects generalized least squares (FE-GLS) to correct for serial correlation, spatial correlation and heteroskedasticity; system estimation using FE-3SLS / 3SLS to estimate direct and indirect effects.
method.outcome_variable: Relative manufacturing employment (share/percentage of workforce employed in manufacturing; country-level).
method.independent_variables: National affluence (real per-capita income, with squared and cubed terms), unbalanced productivity growth (difference in productivity growth between manufacturing and services, including squared term), imports from the South (% of GDP), exports to the South (% of GDP), imports/exports among northern countries (% of GDP), net outflow of FDI (% of GDP).
method.control_variables: Unemployment rate, five-year period dummy variables, country fixed effects (time-invariant country characteristics), lagged explanatory variables (one-year lag).
method.tools_software: Stata (used for postestimation tests and corrections); specific estimation procedures include FE-GLS and FE-3SLS/3SLS (software/packages not itemized beyond Stata).

results.summary: All three hypothesized factors—rising national affluence, unbalanced productivity growth, and globalization (particularly imports from low-wage 'South' countries)—significantly contribute to deindustrialization in advanced economies. Rising consumer affluence is identified as the largest single contributor. Imports from the South have a sizable negative effect on domestic manufacturing employment, larger in magnitude than the positive effects of exports to the South. The paper finds nonlinear (cubic) relationships for affluence and productivity growth with relative manufacturing employment. Decomposition attributes roughly 34% of the decline to rising affluence, 24% to North–South trade (direct effects), over 15% to unbalanced productivity growth, about 15% to unemployment, and roughly 13% to period effects. Robustness checks using FE-3SLS/3SLS corroborate main findings.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Effect of imports from the South on relative manufacturing employment
numerical_results.unit: Coefficient (change in relative manufacturing employment per unit change in imports as % of GDP)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Effect of exports to the South on relative manufacturing employment
numerical_results.unit: Coefficient (change in relative manufacturing employment per unit change in exports as % of GDP)
